(iv)  flood damaged land, consisting of gravel which is slowly spreading with small 
annuals and mosses;  
(v)  the habitats of the Hamadoni alluvial fan, consisting of a network of rivers with 
gravel banks and open water and tugai vegetation on the drier parts of the fan; 
and 
(vi)  the river habitats of the Kizilsu and Pyanj valleys. 
 
20.  Of these ecosystems, the most important are the river and associated tugai vegetation. 
For most of its length the Pyanj river flows either through steep gorges in the Pamirs along its 
upstream end or is heavily developed and over-abstracted along its downstream length in 
Uzbekistan. It is only in its middle section between Chubek and Termez that the river is able to 
develop substantial adjacent wetland systems. Of these, the Hamadoni alluvial fan appears to 
be among the most significant and it is possibly the largest wetland system along the central 
river  section.  Some  80  km  downstream  is  the  Tigrovaya  Balka  Reserve  and  Ramsar  site 
although this lies largely on the tributary Vakhsh river.  
 
    a.  Tugai Vegetation 
 
21.  Tugai vegetation, which supports a large range of specialized animals and birds, is an 
increasingly endangered ecosystem because of clearance for farming and fuel wood. On the 
northern half of the alluvial fan, major tree clearance of the tugai ecosystem took place during 
World War II. Over the next 40 years, the Soviet administration restored the riverine forests 
which were then largely lost again during the Civil War of 1991–1992. The entire low lying area 
around the north of Sayod Hill and extending northwest from Turdiev Jamoat and part of the 
Hamadoni alluvial fan was covered with tugai vegetation in the 1930s. Until 1950, deer, boar 
and pheasant were abundant and the Caspian tiger was believed to be present.  In 1950 a 
deputation went to Moscow for money to reclaim it for agriculture. The result was the foundation 
of Moscovskie (Little Moscow) and the construction of surrounding villages and the Chubek 
irrigation scheme, leading to clearance of the tugai.   
 
22.  Tugai carries out a moisture-keeping function in the embankment and provides a basic 
place of dwelling for some unique animals. Tugai is very useful in holding banks together 
against river erosion and the fact that so much has been cleared on the northern Tajikistan side 
of the river system may partly explain why some of the dominant channels have moved north in 
recent years, leaving much of the Afghan part of the delta higher as well as far more densely 
vegetated. 
 
    b.  Birds   
 
23.  Within the agricultural areas, typical farm birds of Tajikistan can be found. These include 
hoopoe roller, bee-eater, doves, quail, corn crake, lapwing, red-backed shrike, golden oriole, 
larks and most commonly large flocks of myna birds. The cliffs and mountains around Chubek 
support wall creeper, eagle owl, griffon vulture, redstarts, and rock thrushes. 
 
24.  Despite extensive hunting, including duck shooting, which takes place on both sides of 
the border, the birdlife is clearly very rich on the Hamadoni alluvial fan. This includes year round 
residents as well as winter migrants.  
 
    c.  Fish and Fisheries

    f.   Land Use 
 
29.  In the flood plains, the main crops are cotton, cereals, oilseed, potatoes, carrots, onions, 
cucumbers, cabbage, melons, vines, milk, wool, honey and eggs. In addition, orchards or fruit 
trees grown in yards play an important role in the economy.  
 
30.  Adjacent to the main rivers, the stony riverside farmland is often more appropriate for 
vines, fruit trees, and vegetables, especially onions. Cattle also graze within the taller vegetation 
of the tugai. 
 
31.  The rolling loess hills support grazing flocks of sheep, goats, and cattle. In some areas 
that are not too steep the hills are cultivated for wheat and vines. Steep slopes, especially in the 
moister mountainous parts of Tajikistan, are cultivated for fruit trees and potatoes. However, 
especially in the valley of the Yakhsu near Kulyab, the hillsides are too steep to be used for 
much beyond spring grazing for goats.

  7.  Socioeconomic Conditions 
 
    a.   Population 
 
33.  Khatlon province contains most of the low-lying land in Tajikistan. Kulyab is the only 
large town in the project area. The population of the study area is 583,700 according to the 
2005  census,  only  20%  of  whom  were  in  employment,  mainly  in  the  agricultural  sector. 
Approximately 75% of the population is rural. The average monthly income in the agricultural 
sector is US$15 per month. 
 
    b.  Economy 
 
34.  Agriculture is the main economic activity in the region. Together with some housing, 
agricultural  land  was  the  main  casualty  in  the  2005  floods  in  Hamadoni.  The  irrigation 
infrastructure, inherited at the end of the Soviet era, suffers from a lack of investment in routine 
maintenance.  This  has  led  to  a  progressive  loss  of  cultivable  land  and  damage  to 
embankments, intakes, and canals. ”Futures” contracts for cotton production effectively indebt 
the farming community and limit their disposable income. Therefore rural household incomes in 
the project area are generally below the Tajikistan average.  
 
    c.  Urban Development 
 
35.  Villages and towns have long been developed in the valley bottoms. Some are historic 
centers (such as Kulyab town) but many are relatively new towns created in the Soviet era 
(such as Hamadoni—formerly known as Moscovskie). Housing expansion is continuing in an 
uncontrolled manner in flood-prone areas beside the rivers. In the low-lying land between the 
Yakhsu and Kulyab rivers, north of Kulyab, there is a new factory making house construction 
materials.  Kulyab airport and much good agricultural land are located in the valley in spite of 
the flood risk. 
 
d.  Gravel Extraction 
 
36.  Along all the river systems in the study area, gravel extraction for construction materials  
takes place and there are a number of concrete factories. One northeast of Kulyab has been 
badly flooded. In many places the gravel workings lower the valley bottoms and so may draw 
the flood waters toward them and even undermine flood banks.  
 
    e.   Management of Upper Catchments 
 
37.  Mismanagement of upper catchments leading to erosion and heavy sedimentation in 
downstream river valleys is common throughout the world. Grazing is the main land use within 
the uplands surrounding the Kizilsu, Yakhsu and Pyanj valleys. There appears to be little or no 
forest cover surviving.  
 
38.  Where  the  mountainsides  consist  of  Jurassic  and  Paleozoic  rock,  the  problems  of 
erosion are likely to be less acute. Where the hillsides consist of loess or granitic soils, erosion 
is more serious and there is evidence of land slips.

    f.  Existing Development 
 
39.  The Hamadoni flood embankment divides the active and inactive sections of the fan. 
The inactive part is now heavily developed with settlements, infrastructure, and both irrigated 
and rain-fed agriculture in Hamadoni and Farkhor. The adjacent flood plain of the Kizilsu river 
merges with the Hamadoni flood plain and has been developed in a similar way. More than half 
a million people are located in low-lying areas adjacent to, or influenced by, the Pyanj river. The 
majority of them depend directly on agriculture for subsistence and income. 
 
40.  In Afghanistan, 200,000 people or more inhabit low-lying areas on and adjacent to the 
alluvial fan and they are therefore at risk in varying degrees from flooding. 
 
  8.  Impact of Flooding 
 
41.  Although floods are relatively infrequent, there has been considerable direct and indirect 
flood impact from the Pyanj river in Hamadoni and Farkhor districts. This is mainly because of 
the failure of the flood embankments that stretch from Chubek to Metintugai and to a lesser 
extent  the  flood  embankments  between  Sayod  Hill  and  Arabkakul  in  Farkhor  district.  Site 
inspections and discussions with officials indicate that minor failures have occurred from time to 
time over many years, but the major breach near the village of Panjob in 2005 was by far the 
worst. The cumulative impact has been a permanent loss of agricultural land due to smothering 
with gravel and temporary loss of infrastructure such as roads, canals and buildings. There has 
also been indirect flood impact in outlying areas in Farkhor and Vose because the supply of 
irrigation water has been interrupted. 
 
42.  The Kizilsu, Yakhsu and Kulyab rivers run parallel to each other in the relatively narrow 
and well populated valley which constitutes the main settled land in Kulyab district. They flow 
through non-cohesive gravels at a steep gradient and are highly mobile. They create major 
flooding problems throughout the valley and as a result the whole valley needs to be treated 
holistically rather than piecemeal. 
 
43.  In Kulyab town, the Tebolai river creates environmental and flooding challenges that are 
disproportionate to its small size as it flows through the town. Severe environmental issues 
along  the  Tebolai  include  flooding  and  inundiation,  threats  to  public  health,  resettlement, 
schools and a prison. The flooding and pollution problems of the river and the potential for 
upstream flood control structures such as check dams need to be addressed. 
 
44.  The alluvial fan and the flood plain start from the narrow upstream mountain defile 
between Chubek in Tajikistan and Yateh Tepa in Afghanistan and end in the valley constriction 
at near Arabkakul in Afghanistan, some 25-30 km downstream. Nearly all the active fan and 
flood plain lies in Afghanistan. Although there appears to be no formal development in this area, 
it is populated by at least 200,000 people, most of whom practice subsistence agriculture using 
self-help irrigation schemes and stock grazing. The lack of any formal flood protection or flood 
management schemes in this area means that there is a significant and severe risk of flood 
damage.  The  2005  flood  caused  considerable  damage  to  communities  in  Afghanistan. 
Anecdotal reports suggest that at least 16,500 ha of irrigated land and 25,000 farm animals 
were lost.

  1.  Indirect and Trans-boundary Impacts Affecting Afghanistan 
 
46.  The project will involve works at three locations: 
 
(i)  approximately 700 m of river bank protection at, and immediately upstream of, 
the Sayod Hill border post; 
(ii)  approximately 3.5 km of river bank protection near Metintugai village; and

47.  The original flood embankments were constructed along the northern edge of the Pyanj 
river alluvial fan some 50 years ago to protect the irrigated land as it was developed to the 
north. This significantly reduced the active area of the alluvial fan and is likely to have led to 
changes in the hydraulics and topography of the upper fan near Chubek by restricting the lateral 
movement of river channels and gravel bars. It is also likely that there were changes to the 
configuration of sand and silt islands further downstream. However, after more than 50 years, 
the alluvial fan will have completely adjusted to the presence of the embankments. Therefore 
the proposed rehabilitation will not alter the conditions that have been present for more than 50 
years. 
 
48.  The proposed works will have some local impacts on flow patterns and scouring as they 
are situated adjacent to the river, but these effects are unlikely to extend more than a few 
meters into the nearest river channel. As the system of braided channels extends some 5-10 km 
across from Hamadoni toward Afghanistan, the wider effects will be insignificant. Therefore no 
trans-boundary  impacts  are  anticipated  in  relation  to  the  rehabilitation  of  the  flood 
embankments. 
 
  2.  Impact on Ecological Resources 
 
49.  Vegetation has little chance to become established at the northern end of the alluvial fan 
as flood flows scour away any plant that has managed to establish itself. At the southern end of 
the  fan,  the  velocity  of  flows  decreases  to  a  point  where  tugai  vegetation  can  become 
established and survive the flood flows. Before the land was cleared for agriculture, tugai 
vegetation was present along the river banks and on the northern part of the fan.

50.  The ecological value of the project area is high and the alluvial fan can be considered to 
be a wetland of international importance. The proposed project works have a small footprint and 
they are located along 2.7 km of the northern edge of the present tugai and braided river 
system, which covers an area of approximately 100 km2. Therefore the impacts of the proposed

the area. 
 
    a.   Ecological Enhancement of the Project Area 
53.  Tugai is the most important and threatened habitat within the study area as well as being 
a major tool in the management and control of the river system. A community forest will be 
planted along a strip of unconsolidated sands and gravel behind the embankments and will 
cover an area 22 km long and 1 km wide. The aim is to recreate tugai vegetation that would 
have existed in this area before it was cleared for agriculture. The willows, poplars and reeds 
and grasses that characterize tugai vegetation have evolved over many millennia to survive 
inundation by flooding. The community alluvial forest will enhance the project at a number of 
levels. First, the growth of the vegetation will help to bind up the unconsolidated sands and 
gravels. Once it is mature it will help to dissipate the power of any future floods that breach or 
overtop the embankments. Second, it will provide a sustainable source of fuel wood for the local 
community. Third, it will be an important ecological resource as it will re-establish the natural 
vegetation community of the area. This component will be funded by a Japan Fund for Poverty 
Reduction  (JFPR) grant.

vehicle movements, limiting the construction footprint, and scheduling the construction work 
during the dry season.

threat to Afghanistan than may have been the case in the past.

•  Emergence of higher levels of disease due to increased humidity in houses, bad quality of drinking water, 
and anxiety. In the project areas cases of malaria and typhoid were reported after floods. The number of 
people suffering from rheumatism increased. Woman's diseases, high blood pressure and kidney diseases 
became more prevalent among villages residents.     
•  Rising groundwater results in lower agricultural yields (vegetables rot) and in deterioration of drinking 
water quality.   
•  Decline in access to essential services because of the destruction of infrastructure: roads, schools, power 
transmission and communication lines; and irrigation canals. 
•  Increased level of labor migration. During the focus group discussions, more than 80% of both men and 
women noted that, as a result of the floods, the number of labor migrants moving abroad to earn money had  
increased. People use remittances to try to recover from the consequences of the flood.   
 
The Project addresses the core issues raised by households in the project areas in a number of ways.  First, it will 
repair broken embankment areas along the Pyanj river, thereby reducing the likelihood of overall flooding to once in 
100 years, substantially improving the safety of the poor and their assets.  Second, it will provide equipment both to 
ensure adequate maintenance of the repaired embankments and to provide help to communities along tributaries to 
perform essential repairs they cannot handle on their own.  Third, the project will conduct feasibility studies to 
determine what work can be undertaken on the tributaries to increase flood protection for communities that are 
potentially at risk.  Fourth, the project will provide more effective methods of flood risk warning, from risk maps to 
measurement mechanisms. These will enable the Government and communities to be able to better anticipate floods.  
Fifth, the project will work with both the Committee for Emergency Situations and, under a proposed Japan Fund For 
Poverty Reduction (JFPR) grant, with communities directly to ensure all members are prepared to deal with the results 
of floods.  Sixth, under the JFPR project, a significant area will be planted in trees in the project zone, and this area 
will both act to strengthen the Hamadoni embankment and provide a valuable source of firewood and income 
generation for nearby households. 
 
Hamadoni district will benefit directly from the Project because repairs to the embankments will lower the probability of 
floods. The population of the four districts will benefit directly from the increased awareness of the potential for floods 
and their effects, improved preparedness for flood events and heightened readiness to act quickly to limit losses due 
to floods, and better awareness of post-flood requirements to speed recovery and to limit disease, non-agricultural 
losses, and damage to household goods. Finally, work to create both community cohesion and better relations 
between  different  levels  of  government  through  the  Project  and  the  proposed  JFPR  project  will  enhance 
understanding by both sides of conditions and concerns of the poor, and lead to better information flows on how to 
address issues of poverty related to disasters.

district and jamoat leaders and their deputies), district emergency and civil defense authorities, heads of committees 
for affairs of women and children and social issues under districts, international partners (United Nations Development

The Project’s proposed participation strategy involves (i) collaboration between the CES and communities in the

consultations with communities in affected areas to determine their knowledge of previous floods and views on

D.  Gender Development 
 Strategy to maximize impacts on women: 
To maximize their benefits under the Project, women will need access to decision-making, information, and income 
options.  To engage women in decision-making, all levels of government (including the PMU and PIOs) will have at 
least one professional woman directly involved in project activities. To ensure women have access to information, 
women will form 40% of the participants in all courses, and in courses in communities 50%.  Women will be eligible to 
provide labor for local contractors during the construction phase, and contractors will report on the composition of their 
workforces by sex. Their target for unskilled labor will be at least 15% women.
